articles.title: Nirmala Sitharaman Asks Banks To Stay Alert, Focus On Cybersecurity Measures As India-Pak Tensions Mount
creator: ABP Live Business
articles.description: With geopolitical tensions escalating along India‚Äôs borders, Union Minister for Finance and Corporate Affairs Nirmala Sitharaman chaired a high-level meeting on Friday to assess the preparedness of the banking and insurance sectors in addressing operational and cybersecurity risks.The session brought together Managing Directors and Chief Executive Officers from public and private sector banks, as well as insurance firms, alongside key officials from the Department of Financial Services (DFS), RBI, CERT-In, IRDAI, and NPCI.The discussions centred around ensuring robust protection of digital platforms such as UPI and internet banking, and maintaining uninterrupted access to banking services during a period of heightened alert.üëâ Union Minister for Finance and Corporate Affairs Smt. @nsitharaman chairs meeting to review banking sector's operational and cybersecurity preparedness, including digital applications such as internet banking and UPIüëâ FM Smt. @nsitharaman directs all banks to remain fully‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/X1OtHTS2m7‚Äî Ministry of Finance (@FinMinIndia) May 9, 2025Cybersecurity Measures Intensified Across Financial SectorTop executives from the banking sector briefed the Finance Minister on the series of defensive measures implemented to counter cyber threats. ‚ÄúTo guarantee institutional readiness, mock drills have been held encompassing cybersecurity and disaster recovery scenarios at the highest levels. They apprised that phishing attempts are being actively watched, and staff members have received several internal alerts to increase awareness,‚Äù the finance ministry stated.The deployment of Anti-DDoS (Distributed Denial-of-Service) systems has been expanded across the financial ecosystem to fend off potential large-scale attacks. Security Operations Centres (SOCs) and Network Operations Centres (NOCs) are reportedly functioning round-the-clock and are in constant coordination with CERT-In and the National Critical Information Infrastructure Protection Centre (NCIIPC), allowing for real-time threat tracking and information sharing.Sitharaman underlined the critical role of banks in upholding economic stability and urged them to adopt a proactive stance. ‚ÄúThe FM directed all banks to remain fully alert and prepared to deal with any eventuality or crisis, ensuring uninterrupted access to banking & financial services for citizens across the country, especially in border areas,‚Äù the ministry‚Äôs statement said.Also Read : Delhi Airport Issues Travel Advisory As India-Pakistan Tensions EscalateEmergency Protocols, Employee Safety, and Service Continuity StressedThe Finance Minister called for regular audits of core banking and cybersecurity infrastructure to ensure systems remain fortified and continuously monitored. Each bank was asked to appoint two senior officials at headquarters ‚Äî one to oversee cyber-related incidents and the other to manage branch-level operations and cash logistics. These officers are to report incidents to CERT-In and the DFS in real time.Expressing concern for banking staff stationed near conflict zones, Sitharaman directed banks to ensure the safety of employees and their families by working closely with security agencies. She further emphasised that service continuity must not be compromised, stating that ‚Äúpriority must be given to seamless cash availability at ATMs, uninterrupted Unified Payments Interface (UPI) and internet banking services, and continued access to essential banking facilities.‚ÄùInsurance companies were instructed to maintain uninterrupted customer service and process claims swiftly. The Finance Minister also asked sponsor banks to provide strong support to Regional Rural Banks (RRBs), particularly during these testing times.Reiterating the government‚Äôs stance, Sitharaman said that the country‚Äôs banking and financial architecture remains stable and resilient. ‚ÄúThe Government of India is firmly committed to national security and economic stability,‚Äù she said.

articles.title: Gold Prices Surge As India-Pakistan Tensions Escalate, Check Rates Across Cities On May 10
creator: ABP Live Business
articles.description: Gold Rate Today: India holds the position of the second-largest gold consumer globally, trailing only China. A significant portion of the country's gold requirement is met through imports, as recycled gold contributes minimally to the overall supply. This heavy reliance on imported gold makes domestic prices highly sensitive to both international and local dynamics. On the global front, gold is priced in US dollars, which means that shifts in the dollar's strength or major economic developments across the world can directly affect how much Indian buyers pay. Within the country, government-imposed import duties and taxes further shape the price landscape. These additional charges, levied on imported gold, tend to elevate the final price for Indian consumers. Despite these cost fluctuations, gold continues to be a favoured investment in India, valued both as a hedge against inflation and as a symbol of financial security.Here Are The Latest Gold Rates articles.title: Women in 40s should apply these 5 things on face after bathing in summer for glowing skin
articles.description: In summer, the skin gets damaged due to strong sunlight, dust, and sweat. Due to this, many types of problems start occurring on the skin. In summer, most people have to face many skin problems like pimples, blackheads, rashes, tanning, and sunburn. Especially women of increasing age are more harmed by the harmful rays of the sun. Due to this, problems like spots, freckles, wrinkles, and fine lines start occurring on their skin. Also, the face starts looking very dull and lifeless. Therefore, if you are also more than 40 years old, then take extra care of your skin in summer.

articles.description: India's foreign exchange reserves experienced a decrease of $2.06 billion, bringing the total down to $686.06 billion, ending an eight-week streak of gains. The RBI's interventions in the forex market to manage Rupee volatility likely contributed to this fluctuation.

articles.title: Who Is Yalda Hakim? Afghan-Born Journalist Not Afraid To Ask Pakistan The Tough Questions
creator: Kirti Pandey
articles.description: Ever since Indian defence forces launched ‚ÄòOperation Sindoor‚Äô to target terror camps inside Pakistan-Occupied-Kashmir and parts of Pakistan, there have been claims by Pakistan that they do not harbour terrorists, and that India is attacking civilians. While most of the western media seems either ignorant of issues pertaining to the Indian subcontinent, or are indifferent to it, one name stands out: anchor-reporter Yalda Hakim, the 41-year-old woman journalist from Sky News, Australia.Yalda Hakim, the Afghan-born Australian journalist who is now a prominent face on Sky News, has earned international acclaim for her incisive interviews with Pakistani ministers and diplomats ‚Äî unflinchingly questioning them on state-backed terror groups, cross-border attacks, and historical denials. With her sharp questioning, detailed knowledge of South Asian geopolitics, and calm persistence, Hakim has brought uncomfortable truths to the global forefront, challenging narratives and demanding answers where many hesitate.Key Interviews by Yalda Hakim Exposing Pakistan‚Äôs Terror Links1. Interview with Pakistan's Defence Minister Khawaja AsifIn a revealing conversation, Defence Minister Khawaja Asif acknowledged Pakistan's history of supporting and funding terrorist organisations as proxies, referring to it as "dirty work" done for the United States over three decades. This admission was unexpected and garnered significant attention. 2. Interview with Mohammad Faisal, Pakistan's High Commissioner to the UK During a discussion on the Pahalgam terror attack, High Commissioner Mohammad Faisal claimed Pakistan's commitment to peace. Hakim countered by highlighting Pakistan's lack of cooperation in investigations of major terrorist attacks in India, such as the 2001 Parliament attack, the 2008 Mumbai attacks, and the 2016 and 2019 Uri and Pulwama attacks. Her sharp and unrelenting questioning left Faisal visibly unsettled. 3. Interview with Pakistan's Information Minister Attaullah TararWhen Minister Tarar denied the existence of terrorist camps in Pakistan, Hakim reminded him of Defence Minister Asif's admission on her show about Pakistan's support for terror groups. She further cited instances where Pakistani leaders, including General Pervez Musharraf and Benazir Bhutto, acknowledged such support, effectively challenging Tarar's claims.‚ÄúThere are no terrorist camps in Pakistan‚Äù says Pakistan‚Äôs Information Minister Attaullah Tatar.I spoke to him as India fired missiles into Pakistani-controlled territory in several locations early Wednesday. India says it is targeting ‚Äúterrorist infrastructure‚Äù. pic.twitter.com/3ZOEww5dkK‚Äî Yalda Hakim (@SkyYaldaHakim) May 7, 2025Who Is Yalda Hakim?Yalda Hakim is an acclaimed Australian journalist and broadcaster, currently serving as the Lead World News Presenter for Sky News. Born on June 26, 1983, in Kabul, Afghanistan, her early life was marked by upheaval. At just six months old, her family fled the Soviet-Afghan War, undertaking a perilous journey on horseback to Pakistan. After two years, they resettled in Sydney, Australia, where Hakim was raised.Hakim's educational journey began at Parramatta West Public School and Macarthur Girls High School in Sydney. She pursued a Bachelor of Arts in Media at Macquarie University from 2002 to 2004, followed by a Diploma in Journalism from Macleay College in 2005. She furthered her studies with a Bachelor of Arts in Journalism via distance education at Monash University between 2007 and 2009. Her journalism career commenced with a cadetship at SBS's World News Australia, where she quickly gained recognition for her reporting. Hakim's reporting prowess led her to co-host SBS's 'Dateline' in 2011. In 2012, she joined BBC World News, where she became a prominent presenter and reporter, known for her in-depth coverage of global conflicts and high-profile interviews. Her notable work includes reporting on the collapse of the Afghan government in 2021 and producing documentaries highlighting the impact of the Taliban's return to power on Afghan women and girls. Hakim grabbed headlines when she got a call from Taliban spokesman Suhail Shaheen on live TV, and the 30-minute interview that followed is still talked about. It was a time when Afghan President Ashaf Ghani was fleeing the country as the Taliban prepared to capture Kabul, and Hakim used her chance to "hold the Taliban to account" by asking some tough questions. In July 2023, she transitioned to Sky News, where she currently hosts 'The World with Yalda Hakim'. Hakin is known for her work beyond journalism too. In 2018, she established the Yalda Hakim Foundation, aiming to provide scholarships and educational opportunities to young Afghan women. The foundation has partnered with institutions like Oxford University to offer fully-funded programmes for Afghan students. Hakim is multilingual, fluent in English, Dari, Urdu, Hindi, Persian, and Pashto, and has been learning Mandarin. Her familiarity with the Indian subcontinent and its issues reflects in her journalism, particularly in her coverage of regional politics and South Asian diaspora issues. She is married to Abed Rashid, and they have one child. Kirti Pandey is a senior independent journalist.

articles.title: Judge Halts Trump's Controversial Government Overhaul
articles.description: Judge Halts Trump's Controversial Government Overhaul A federal judge has mandated a temporary halt to President Donald Trump's expansive government overhaul plan, asserting that the administration lacks congressional authorization for such large-scale changes. This decision affects widespread staffing cuts and the restructuring of federal agencies.The ruling, issued by U.S. District Judge Susan Illston in San Francisco, came after a coalition of unions, non-profits, and local governments challenged the administration's plans. The temporary restraining order prevents mass layoffs known as 'reductions in force' for 14 days as the administration faces legal pushback.Judge Illston emphasized that significant restructuring of federal agencies requires congressional approval. The White House has yet to comment on the decision, but the judgement sets a precedent against such unilateral executive actions, underlining the legal friction surrounding President Trump's attempts to streamline government operations.

articles.title: India-Pakistan Tension Live: India Hits Back After Pak Targets 26 Locations
creator: ABP Live News
articles.description: India-Pakistan Tension Live: A fresh wave of drone attacks was launched by Pakistan, for the second night on Friday, targeting 26 locations in Jammu and Kashmir, Punjab, Rajasthan, and Gujarat. The defence ministry assured that the situation was under "close and constant watch", and that there was no cause for panic.The defence ministry also stated that Pakistan's attempt to strike vital installations, including air bases and airports, were thwarted successfully. However, a family was injured during an attack in Punjab's Ferozpur, which was carried out after darkness fell. At the time, all the states that border Pakistan were under night-long blackout.The defence ministry later confirmed that an armed drone targeted a civilian area in Ferozpur, resulting in injuries to members of a local family. The locations long the International Border and Line of Control with Pakistan which were attacked last night include Baramulla, Srinagar, Awantipora, Nagrota, Jammu, Ferozpur, Pathankot, Fazilka, Lalgarh Jatta, Jaisalmer, Barmer, Bhuj, Kuarbet, and Lakhi Nala.These fresh strikes were reported just a day after India successfully foiled an attempt by the Pakistani military to target Indian military sites with drones and missiles.In Baramulla district, the night sky lit up as Indian forces shot down several Pakistani drones. Explosions rang out and warning sirens blared across parts of the Jammu region and south Kashmir, causing widespread power outages.In Srinagar, loudspeakers from mosques urged residents to turn off their lights as a safety measure. Blasts were also heard near Srinagar airport and countermeasures were deployed to neutralise the suspected drone threat.Officials also confirmed that drones had been spotted and engaged in areas like Udhampur and Nagrota in Jammu, as well as Kupwara in north Kashmir. Meanwhile, intense shelling was reported along the IB in Jammu‚Äôs Suchetgarh and Ramgarh sectors, as well as in Samba district.Jammu and Kashmir Chief Minister Omar Abdullah on Friday night chaired a meeting to review relief efforts and preparedness in border districts following intense cross-border shelling.Tensions between India and Pakistan escalated sharply after the Indian armed forces carried out precision strikes on terror launchpads in Pakistan and Pakistan-occupied Kashmir (PoK) on Wednesday. The operation was a direct response to the April 22 terrorist attack in Pahalgam, Jammu and Kashmir, which killed 26 people,mostly tourists.
